Willkommen zur Ausgabe 21 des Ubuntu Weekly Newsletter für die Woche vom 29. Oktober - 11. November 2006. Nach langer Abwesenheit sind wir wieder zurück. In dieser Ausgabe behandeln wir die Ubuntu-Entwicklerkonferenz in Mountain View, die Eröffnung von Feisty, den Planungszyklus, neue Teams und vieles mehr.

Ältere Ausgaben des Ubuntu Weekly Newsletter können immer unter https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuWeeklyNewsletter gefunden werden.

=== Allgemeine Community News ===

==== Ubuntu-Entwicklerkonferenz Mountain View (Ubuntu Developer Summit Mountain View) ====

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">The Ubuntu Developer Summit in Mountain View, California wrapped up on the 11th of November. It was a busy week of talking, meeting up with people, drinking and dancing (just ask Jono Bacon about the "bottle dance"). As with previous development summits, this one covers the next release and all the various goals people have for it. One thing was clear, community matters. This was shown in all the community related specs discussed at the summit. There is a detailed section below covering the process for sheparding specs from idea to release goal.
|}

Die Ubuntu-Entwicklerkonferenz in Mountain View Kalifornien fand am 11. November statt. Es war eine arbeitsreiche Woche von Gesprächen, Treffen mit anderen Leuten, Trinken und Tanzen (frage einfach mal Jono Bacon über den "Flaschentanz"). Wie auch bei den vorherigen Konferenzen, ging es bei dieser um das nächste Release und all die verschiedenen Ziele, die die Leute dafür haben. Eines war klar, die Community ist wichtig. Dies wurde durch die vielen Communitybezogenen Anforderungen gezeigt, die auf der Konferenz diskutiert wurden. Weiter unten ist ein detailierterer Abschnitt, der den Prozess von einer Idee bis zum Releaseziel behandelt.

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">Joe 'Zonker' Brockmeier of Linux.com covered the summit quite extensively, in two separate reports. You can read them at http://community.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/11/10/168227&tid=53 and http://community.linux.com/community/06/11/13/2112259.shtml?tid=53&tid=96.
|}

Joe 'Zonker' Brockmeier von Linux.com behandelte die Konferenz in zwei Berichten ziemlich ausführlich. Sie sind unter http://community.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/11/10/168227&tid=53 und http://community.linux.com/community/06/11/13/2112259.shtml?tid=53&tid=96 nachzulesen.

=== Feisty wird geschmiedet (Forging Feisty) ===

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">The Ubuntu Developer Summit provides developers and contributors with a unique opportunity to collaborate and work together. This month, Ubuntu participants from around the globe gathered at the Googleplex in Mountain View, California to set goals and make decisions that will shape Feisty Fawn. The meeting facilitated coordination between the disparate sub-teams that make up the core of Ubuntu's most dedicated contributors.
|}

Der Ubuntu-Entwicklerkonferenz bietet Entwicklern und Mitarbeitern eine einzigartige Chance miteinander- und zusammenzuarbeiten. In diesem Monat trafen sich Beteiligte des Ubuntu Projekt aus der ganzen Welt im Googleplex in Mountain View, California, um Ziele auszuloten und Entscheidungen zu treffen, die den Rahmen von Feisty Fawn bilden werden. Das Treffen  erleichterte die Koordination zwischen den verschiedenen Teams, die den Kern der engagiertesten Mitarbeiter von Ubuntu bilden.  

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">The bread and butter of a nascent Ubuntu feature is the "Specification" or "spec", in developer shorthand. A spec is a written suggestion of what a new Ubuntu feature should be like.
|}

Essentiell bei einem entstehenden Ubuntu Feature ist die "Specification" oder "spec", Ein "spec ist ein geschriebener Vorschlag, wie das neue Ubuntu Feature aussehen soll. 

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">Specs have always driven the Ubuntu development cycle, and as such, they need to be prioritized according to the amount of developer time available. At a casual glance, the spec lists () for Ubuntu is long, largely because anybody can create a specification. However, only certain people have the authoirty to determine which specs are worthy of discussion at a meeting like the Ubuntu Developer Summit in Mountain View, and fewer still can approve a spec for official inclusion in Ubuntu. Since the spec list reflects the direction of Ubuntu development, it provides useful insight into the community's goals for upcoming releases.
|}

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">So, how do specs go from an idea to a plan? Most approved specs go through a three step implementation process. After they are created, specs are usually proposed at a meeting for discussion. In the Ubuntu world, spec discussions take place at biannual Ubuntu Developer Summits, like the recent one held in Mountain View. If a spec is accepted for evaluation at a meeting, the first phase is dicussion. Topics are scheduled for a BOF (Birds of a Feather) session. These usually include the registrant of the spec (the progenitor of the bright idea), an assignee, a drafter (responsible for writing the spec on the Ubuntu Wiki), and an approver. For this Ubuntu Summit, there were about 10 rooms available for people to gather and discuss specs. These discussions are usually where developers hash out implementation details, gather information, research upstream issues, and generally discuss the nature of the proposed features. After this, there is a session in which the drafter gathers the notes from the discussion, fleshes out the implementation section of the spec, and refines use cases. A "use case" is a software engineering term that defines the feature from the perspective of a user. This helps developers visualize potential requirements for the feature.
|}

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">After drafting, a team of editors reviews the spec. The editors check to ensure that the spec is well written, comprehensible, and in conformance with the quality guidelines expected by Ubuntu. So, why go through all the trouble to document the process in excruciating detail? Although a majority of Ubuntu developers are present at the summit, not all are able to attend. Even an excellent spec may not be implemented due to lack of developer resources. By outlining potential features in detail, a volunteer developer can cultivate an understanding of what needs to be done to get the feature finished. This transparency allows people to build upon well documented ideas, and possibly collaborate with others to get the features they want into Ubuntu. This is why the spec editors help refine the specs to make them as good as possible.
|}

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">After the editors are satisfied with their creation, it finally enters the "Pending Approval" stage. From here, senior Ubuntu developers have the final say and can choose to grace a spec with the coveted "Approved" definition, with a matching priority. From here most specs will be implemented. Some get finished, some might be deferred to another release, and some might be split into several smaller specs. Some might languish around for a few releases, it all really depends on available resources and time until release.
|}

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">As the Ubuntu community continues to grow, the number of specs will continue to increase as well. This is why expanding the Ubuntu developer community continues to be an important part of the Ubuntu project.
|}

=== Änderungen in Feisty ===

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">The floodgates for the new Feisty opened this week, with a lot of predictable changes. After the toolchain (glibc, compilers, etc.) went throught their rebuild process, the first new package was Ben Collins' 2.6.19 kernel, one of many uploads of the new .19 kernel of the following two weeks.
|}

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">As can be counted on for every release, the latest GNOME development release, 2.17, has started to appear. Held up by the UDS, the upload, by Sebastian and Daniel, has trickled in over the last two weeks, rather than in a single few days. Packages included epiphany-browser 2.17.2, gnome-utils 2.17.0, metacity 1:2.17.2, gtkhtml3.8 3.13.2, file-roller 2.17.2, gnome-vfs2 2.16.2, deskbar-applet 2.17.2, vino 2.17.2, gnome-icon-theme 2.17.2.1, gnome-themes 2.17.2,  gnome-games 1:2.17.2 (including two new games, sudoku and chess), gnome-system-monitor 2.17.2.1, eel2 2.16.1, and totem 2.17.2. You can read more about GNOME 2.17 at http://live.gnome.org/TwoPointSeventeen.
|}

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| <tablestyle="background:#F1F1ED">Barely slowed down by the Edgy release, the Telepathy team continued to push the latest and greatest of this communication framework into Ubuntu. The regular, Jabber-only branch of gossip also had a new release, with gossip 09.19.
|}

=== Updates and security releases for 6.06 and 6.10 ===
